content_sections.title:
Java Scanner

Method

Example
Print the value of every floating point number in the string
content_sections.content:
:
// Create a scanner object
Scanner myObj = new Scanner("The probability is 45.6 percent");

// Print the value of every floating point number in the scanner
while (myObj.has
  if (myObj.has
    System.out.println(myObj.
  } else {
    myObj.
  }
}
Definition and Usage
The

method returns a
float
value containing the number represented by the 
The scanner is able to interpret digit groupings, such as using a comma for separating groups of 3 digits. The format of the groupings and the character used as a decimal point depend on the locale settings of the scanner, which can be changed with the
useLocale()
method.
What is a token?
A token is a sequence of characters separated from other tokens by delimiters. The default delimiter is a block of whitespace characters but it can be changed with the
useDelimiter()
method.
Syntax
public float 
Technical Details
Returns:
A
float
value containing the number represented by the token.
Throws:

content_sections.title: InputMismatchException
content_sections.content: - If the token does not represent a valid number.

content_sections.title: NoSuchElementException
content_sections.content: - If there are no more tokens in the scanner.

content_sections.title: IllegalStateException
content_sections.content:
- If the scanner has been closed.

summary: This tutorial covers Java ScannernextFloat()Method concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use Java ScannernextFloat()Method effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples.
